title: Getting started with resquin
text: short tutorial describe functions resquin can use technical level. substantive introduction see (forthcoming) article Using resquin practice. Functions resquin calculate response quality indicators survey data stored data frame tibble. functions assume input data frame structured following way: data frame wide format, meaning row represents one respondent, column represents one variable. variables number response options. variables order questions respondents saw taking survey. responses integer values. Missing values set NA. (resp_styles()) Reverse keyed variables original form. items recoded.

title: Getting started with resquin
text: Consider following (fake) data set survey responses. data set contains responses three survey questions (var_a,var_b var_c) ten respondents. three survey question allow responses scale 1 5. respondents missing values, set NA. Lets use data set calculate response quality indicators.
code: # A test data set with three items and ten respondents testdata <- data.frame(   var_a = c(1,4,3,5,3,2,3,1,3,NA),   var_b = c(2,5,2,3,4,1,NA,2,NA,NA),   var_c = c(1,2,3,NA,3,4,4,5,NA,NA))  testdata #>    var_a var_b var_c #> 1      1     2     1 #> 2      4     5     2 #> 3      3     2     3 #> 4      5     3    NA #> 5      3     4     3 #> 6      2     1     4 #> 7      3    NA     4 #> 8      1     2     5 #> 9      3    NA    NA #> 10    NA    NA    NA

title: Getting started with resquin
text: Response styles capture systematic shifts respondents response behavior. example, respondents extreme response style may choose lowest highest categories (example 1 5) mid-point responder choose midpoint scale (example 3). calculate response styles can use resp_styles() function. First, need specify data argument x. , need specify minimum maximum scales used questionnaire (scale_min scale_max respectively). Remember questions included must number response options. discuss arguments min_valid_responses normalize later. resulting data frame contains five columns corresponding middle response style (MRS), acquiescence response style (ARS), disaquiescence response style (DRS), extreme response style (ERS), non-extreme response style (NERS) - can learn response styles help file function using ?resp_styles. respondent receives one value indicator, given can calculated. normalize set TRUEthe values expressed share responses respondent can attributed response style. example, respondent one ERS value 0.67 meaning two three responses can identified extreme responses. hand, respondent one mid-point response, leading value 0 MRS column. Instead calculating proportions, can extract counts responses can attributed response option setting normalize FALSE. Finally, can decide include exclude respondents receiving response style values setting min_valid_responses, can take values 0 1. min_valid_responses sets share valid responses (.e. non-missing responses) respondent must receive response style values. value 0 indicates response style values calculated respondents, regardless whether missing values. value 1 indicates response styles calculated respondents valid responses variables. Values 0 1 indicate share responses need valid included response style calculations.
code: library(resquin) # Calculating response style indicators for all respondents with no missing values results_response_styles <- resp_styles(   x = testdata,   scale_min = 1,   scale_max = 5,   min_valid_responses = 1, # Excludes respondents with less than 100% valid responses   normalize = T)  # Presents results in percent of all responses  round(results_response_styles,2) #>     MRS  ARS  DRS  ERS NERS #> 1  0.00 0.00 1.00 0.67 0.33 #> 2  0.00 0.67 0.33 0.33 0.67 #> 3  0.67 0.00 0.33 0.00 1.00 #> 4    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 5  0.67 0.33 0.00 0.00 1.00 #> 6  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.33 0.67 #> 7    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 8  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.67 0.33 #> 9    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 10   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA

title: Getting started with resquin
text: resp_distributions() calculates indicators reflect location variability responses within respondent. resp_distributions() works similar resp_styles(): need specify data argument can include exclude respondents calculations based amount missing data exhibit (explanation see paragraph ). resulting data frame contains eight columns: n_na: number intra-individual missing answers prop_na: proportion intra-individual missing responses ii_mean: intra-individual mean ii_median: intra-individual median ii_sd: intra-individual standard deviation mahal: Mahalanobis distance per respondent. can learn response distribution indicators using `?resp_distributions``
code: # Calulating response distribution indicators for all respondents with no missing values results_resp_distributions <- resp_distributions(   x = testdata,   min_valid_responses = 1) # Excludes respondents with less than 100% valid responses  round(results_resp_distributions,2) #>    n_na prop_na ii_mean ii_sd ii_median mahal #> 1     0    0.00    1.33  0.58         1  2.04 #> 2     0    0.00    3.67  1.53         4  1.60 #> 3     0    0.00    2.67  0.58         3  1.38 #> 4     1    0.33      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 5     0    0.00    3.33  0.58         3  0.97 #> 6     0    0.00    2.33  1.53         2  1.38 #> 7     1    0.33      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 8     0    0.00    2.67  2.08         2  1.88 #> 9     2    0.67      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 10    3    1.00      NA    NA        NA    NA

code: @Manual{,   title = {resquin: Response Quality Indicators for Survey Research},   author = {Matthias Roth and Nivedita Bhaktha and Matthias Bluemke and Thomas Knopf and Fabienne Krämer and Clemens Lechner and Çağla Yildiz},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.2.9000, https://matroth.github.io/resquin/},   url = {https://github.com/MatRoth/resquin}, }

title: Response Quality Indicators for Survey Research
text: resquin (response quality indicators) provides functions calculate survey data quality indicators help identifying low-quality responses (Bhaktha, Silber, Lechner 2024; Curran 2016; Vaerenbergh Thomas 2013). resp_styles() resp_distributions() provide response quality indicators geared towards multi-item scales matrix questions. multi-item scales matrix questions present survey respondents multiple questions response format, meaning number labeling response options. moment, resquin provides two functions: resp_styles() - Calculates response style indicators (e.g. extreme response style middle response style). resp_distributions() - Calculates response distribution indicators (e.g. intra-individual mean standard deviation set survey questions). Two functions planned: resp_patterns - Calculates response pattern indicators (e.g. straightlining) resp_times - Calculates response time indicators (e.g. median item response time) information use resquin see vignettes Getting started resquin resquin practice. resquin still active development. Please use github issues file questions bug reports send directly matthias.roth@gesis.org. happy receive feedback!

title: Response Quality Indicators for Survey Research
text: resquin available via CRAN github. install resquin CRAN github, can use one following commands:
code: # Install resquin via CRAN install.packages("resquin")  # Install development version of resquin with devtools devtools::install_github("https://github.com/MatRoth/resquin")  # Install development version of resquin with pak pak::pak("https://github.com/MatRoth/resquin")

title: Response Quality Indicators for Survey Research
text: use resquin, supply data frame containing survey responses wide format either resp_styles() resp_distributions(). information use resquin see vignettes Getting started resquin resquin practice.
code: # load resquin library(resquin)  # A test data set with three items and ten respondents testdata <- data.frame(   var_a = c(1,4,3,5,3,2,3,1,3,NA),   var_b = c(2,5,2,3,4,1,NA,2,NA,NA),   var_c = c(1,2,3,NA,3,4,4,5,NA,NA))  testdata #>    var_a var_b var_c #> 1      1     2     1 #> 2      4     5     2 #> 3      3     2     3 #> 4      5     3    NA #> 5      3     4     3 #> 6      2     1     4 #> 7      3    NA     4 #> 8      1     2     5 #> 9      3    NA    NA #> 10    NA    NA    NA  # Calculate response style indicators per respondent resp_styles(x = testdata,             scale_min = 1,             scale_max = 5) |> # Specify scale minimum and maximum   round(2) #>     MRS  ARS  DRS  ERS NERS #> 1  0.00 0.00 1.00 0.67 0.33 #> 2  0.00 0.67 0.33 0.33 0.67 #> 3  0.67 0.00 0.33 0.00 1.00 #> 4    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 5  0.67 0.33 0.00 0.00 1.00 #> 6  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.33 0.67 #> 7    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 8  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.67 0.33 #> 9    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 10   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA  # Calculate response distribution indicators per respondent resp_distributions(x = testdata) |>   round(2) #>    n_na prop_na ii_mean ii_sd ii_median mahal #> 1     0    0.00    1.33  0.58         1  2.04 #> 2     0    0.00    3.67  1.53         4  1.60 #> 3     0    0.00    2.67  0.58         3  1.38 #> 4     1    0.33      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 5     0    0.00    3.33  0.58         3  0.97 #> 6     0    0.00    2.33  1.53         2  1.38 #> 7     1    0.33      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 8     0    0.00    2.67  2.08         2  1.88 #> 9     2    0.67      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 10    3    1.00      NA    NA        NA    NA

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: Compute response distribution indicators responses multi-item scales matrix questions.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: x data frame containing survey responses wide format. information see section "Data requirements" . min_valid_responses numeric 0 1. Defines share valid responses respondent must calculate response quality indicators. Default 1.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: Returns data frame response quality indicators per respondent. Dimensions: Rows: Equal number rows x. Columns: Six, one response distribution indicator.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: following response distribution indicators calculated per respondent: n_na: number intra-individual missing answers prop_na: proportion intra-individual missing responses ii_mean: intra-individual mean ii_median: intra-individual median ii_sd:  intra-individual standard deviation mahal: mahalanobis distance per respondent. Intra-individual response variability (ii_sd) proposed measure insufficient effort responding (Dunn et al., 2018) distinguish random conscientious responding (Marjanovic et al, 2015). Intra-individual location indicators can used asses average location responses set questions (ii_mean, ii_median). Mahalanobis distance outlier detection indicator. represents distance participants responses center multivariate normal distribution defined data respondents.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: resp_distributions() assumes data comes multi-item scales matrix questions, number labeling response options many questions. input data frame must structured following way: data frame wide format, meaning row represents one respondent, column represents one variable. responses integer values. Missing values set NA.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: interpretation indicators depends whether response data negatively worded questions reversed : reverse data negatively worded questions want assess average response patterns (Dunn et al., 2018). Reverse data negatively worded questions want assess whether responses distributed randomly respect assumed latent variable (Marjanovic et al., 2015).

what: Mahalanobis distance could not be calculated
title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: certain circumstances, mahalanobis distance can calculated. may high collinearity (correlation variables) many missing values. Although can happen survey research data, message can also indicate something data "" due one reasons stated . manual inspection low-quality responses can next step.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: Dunn, Alexandra M., Eric D. Heggestad, Linda R. Shanock, Nels Theilgard. 2018. “Intra-Individual Response Variability Indicator Insufficient Effort Responding: Comparison Indicators Relationships Individual Differences.” Journal Business Psychology 33(1):105–21. doi: 10.1007/s10869-016-9479-0. Marjanovic, Zdravko, Ronald Holden, Ward Struthers, Robert Cribbie, Esther Greenglass. 2015. “Inter-Item Standard Deviation (ISD): Index Discriminates Conscientious Random Responders.” Personality Individual Differences 84:79–83. doi: 10.1016/j.paid.2014.08.021.

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
text: Matthias Roth, Matthias Bluemke & Clemens Lechner

title: Compute response distribution indicators — resp_distributions
code: # A small test data set with ten respondents # and responses to three survey questions # with response scales from 1 to 5. testdata <- data.frame(   var_a = c(1,4,3,5,3,2,3,1,3,NA),   var_b = c(2,5,2,3,4,1,NA,2,NA,NA),   var_c = c(1,2,3,NA,3,4,4,5,NA,NA))  # Calculate response distribution indicators resp_distributions(x = testdata) |>     round(2) #>    n_na prop_na ii_mean ii_sd ii_median mahal #> 1     0    0.00    1.33  0.58         1  2.04 #> 2     0    0.00    3.67  1.53         4  1.60 #> 3     0    0.00    2.67  0.58         3  1.38 #> 4     1    0.33      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 5     0    0.00    3.33  0.58         3  0.97 #> 6     0    0.00    2.33  1.53         2  1.38 #> 7     1    0.33      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 8     0    0.00    2.67  2.08         2  1.88 #> 9     2    0.67      NA    NA        NA    NA #> 10    3    1.00      NA    NA        NA    NA  # Include respondents with NA values by decreasing the # necessary number of valid responses per respondent.  resp_distributions(       x = testdata,       min_valid_responses = 0.2) |>    round(2) #>    n_na prop_na ii_mean ii_sd ii_median mahal #> 1     0    0.00    1.33  0.58       1.0  2.27 #> 2     0    0.00    3.67  1.53       4.0  1.68 #> 3     0    0.00    2.67  0.58       3.0  1.05 #> 4     1    0.33    4.00  1.41       4.0  2.21 #> 5     0    0.00    3.33  0.58       3.0  1.24 #> 6     0    0.00    2.33  1.53       2.0  1.29 #> 7     1    0.33    3.50  0.71       3.5  0.71 #> 8     0    0.00    2.67  2.08       2.0  2.24 #> 9     2    0.67    3.00   NaN       3.0  0.24 #> 10    3    1.00      NA    NA        NA    NA

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: Calculates response style indicators matrix questions multi-item scales.

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
code: resp_styles(x, scale_min, scale_max, min_valid_responses = 1, normalize = TRUE)

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: x data frame containing survey responses wide format. information see section "Data requirements" . scale_min numeric. Minimum scale provided. scale_max numeric. Maximum scale provided. min_valid_responses numeric 0 1. Defines share valid responses respondent must calculate response style indicators. normalize logical. TRUE, counts response style indicators divided number non-missing responses per respondent. Default TRUE.

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: Returns data frame response style indicators per respondent. Rows: Equal number rows x. Columns: Five, one response style indicator.

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: Response styles capture systematic shifts respondents response behavior. resp_styles() aimed multi-item scales matrix questions use number response options many questions. following response style indicators calculated per respondent: Middle response style (MRS), acquiescence response style (ARS), disacquiescence response style (DARS), extreme response style (ERS) non-extreme response style (NERS). response style indicators calculated following way MRS: Sum mid point responses. ARS: Sum responses larger midpoint. DARS: Sum responses lower midpoint. ERS: Sum lowest highest category responses. NERS: Sum responses lowest highest respnose category. Note ARS DRS assume polarity scale positive. means higher numerical values indicate agreement lower numerical values indicate disagreement. MRS can calculated scale numeric midpoint. Also note response style literature fragmented (Bhaktha et al., 2024). Response styles calculated resp_styles() based van Vaerenbergh & Thomas (2024). However, used name non-extreme response style (NERS) instead mild response style, emphasize NERS inverse ERS. appear literature (NERS example see Wetzel et al. (2013)). Consult literature field research find appropriate names response style indicators calculated .

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: resp_styles() assumes input data frame structured following way: data frame wide format, meaning row represents one respondent, column represents one variable. variables order questions respondents saw taking survey. Reverse keyed variables original form. items recoded. responses integer values. Questions number response options. Missing values set NA.

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: Bhaktha, Nivedita, Henning Silber, Clemens Lechner. 2024. „Characterizing response quality surveys multi-item scales: unified framework“. OSF-preprtint: https://osf.io/9gs67/ van Vaerenbergh, Y., T. D. Thomas. 2013. „Response Styles Survey Research: Literature Review Antecedents, Consequences, Remedies“. International Journal Public Opinion Research 25(2):195–217. doi: 10.1093/ijpor/eds021. Wetzel, Eunike, Claus H. Carstensen, und Jan R. Böhnke. 2013. „Consistency Extreme Response Style Non-Extreme Response Style across Traits“. Journal Research Personality 47(2):178–89. doi: 10.1016/j.jrp.2012.10.010.

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
text: Matthias Roth, Matthias Bluemke & Clemens Lechner

title: Compute response style indicators — resp_styles
code: # A test data set with ten respondents # and responses to three survey questions # with response scales from 1 to 5. testdata <- data.frame(   var_a = c(1,4,3,5,3,2,3,1,3,NA),   var_b = c(2,5,2,3,4,1,NA,2,NA,NA),   var_c = c(1,2,3,NA,3,4,4,5,NA,NA))  # Calculate response distribution indicators resp_styles(testdata,             scale_min = 1,             scale_max = 5) |>    round(2) # round to second decimal #>     MRS  ARS  DRS  ERS NERS #> 1  0.00 0.00 1.00 0.67 0.33 #> 2  0.00 0.67 0.33 0.33 0.67 #> 3  0.67 0.00 0.33 0.00 1.00 #> 4    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 5  0.67 0.33 0.00 0.00 1.00 #> 6  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.33 0.67 #> 7    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 8  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.67 0.33 #> 9    NA   NA   NA   NA   NA #> 10   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA  # Include respondents with NA values by decreasing the # necessary number of valid responses per respondent. resp_styles(testdata,             scale_min = 1,             scale_max = 5,             min_valid_responses = 0.2) |>    round(2) # round to second decimal #>     MRS  ARS  DRS  ERS NERS #> 1  0.00 0.00 1.00 0.67 0.33 #> 2  0.00 0.67 0.33 0.33 0.67 #> 3  0.67 0.00 0.33 0.00 1.00 #> 4  0.50 0.50 0.00 0.50 0.50 #> 5  0.67 0.33 0.00 0.00 1.00 #> 6  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.33 0.67 #> 7  0.50 0.50 0.00 0.00 1.00 #> 8  0.00 0.33 0.67 0.67 0.33 #> 9  1.00 0.00 0.00 0.00 1.00 #> 10   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA  # Get counts of responses attributable to response styles. resp_styles(testdata,             scale_min = 1,             scale_max = 5,             normalize = FALSE) #>    MRS ARS DRS ERS NERS #> 1    0   0   3   2    1 #> 2    0   2   1   1    2 #> 3    2   0   1   0    3 #> 4   NA  NA  NA  NA   NA #> 5    2   1   0   0    3 #> 6    0   1   2   1    2 #> 7   NA  NA  NA  NA   NA #> 8    0   1   2   2    1 #> 9   NA  NA  NA  NA   NA #> 10  NA  NA  NA  NA   NA
